title: Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACE) Score
description: Screens for adverse childhood experiences to assess risk of health problems in adulthood

parameters.name: emotional_abuse
parameters.description: Did a parent or other adult in the household often or very often swear at you, insult you, put you down, or humiliate you? OR act in a way that made you afraid that you might be physically hurt?

parameters.name: physical_abuse
parameters.description: Did a parent or other adult in the household often or very often push, grab, slap, or throw something at you? OR ever hit you so hard that you had marks or were injured?

parameters.name: sexual_abuse
parameters.description: Did an adult or person at least 5 years older than you ever touch or fondle you or have you touch their body in a sexual way? OR attempt or actually have oral, anal, or vaginal intercourse with you?

parameters.name: emotional_neglect
parameters.description: Did you often or very often feel that no one in your family loved you or thought you were important or special? OR your family didn't look out for each other, feel close to each other, or support each other?

parameters.name: physical_neglect
parameters.description: Did you often or very often feel that you didn't have enough to eat, had to wear dirty clothes, and had no one to protect you? OR your parents were too drunk or high to take care of you or take you to the doctor if you needed it?

parameters.name: parental_separation
parameters.description: Were your parents ever separated or divorced?

parameters.name: mother_treated_violently
parameters.description: Was your mother or stepmother often or very often pushed, grabbed, slapped, or had something thrown at her? OR sometimes, often, or very often kicked, bitten, hit with a fist, or hit with something hard? OR ever repeatedly hit over at least a few minutes or threatened with a gun or knife?

parameters.name: household_substance_abuse
parameters.description: Did you live with anyone who was a problem drinker or alcoholic or who used street drugs?

parameters.name: household_mental_illness
parameters.description: Was a household member depressed or mentally ill, or did a household member attempt suicide?

parameters.name: household_member_incarcerated
parameters.description: Did a household member go to prison?

ranges.interpretation: Low risk for health problems related to childhood trauma. This represents the lowest risk category, though it doesn't guarantee absence of all health risks.
Moderate risk for health problems. While some increased risk exists, many people with scores in this range lead healthy lives. Protective factors and resilience can significantly mitigate risks.

High risk for health problems including depression, substance abuse, and chronic diseases. Early intervention and trauma-informed care can be beneficial. Consider screening for mental health issues and providing appropriate support.

Very high risk for serious health problems including mental illness, substance abuse, chronic diseases, and early death. Strong recommendation for trauma-informed care, mental health screening, and comprehensive support services. However, with appropriate interventions and support, positive outcomes are still possible.

references: Felitti VJ, Anda RF, Nordenberg D, et al. Relationship of childhood abuse and household dysfunction to many of the leading causes of death in adults. The Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACE) Study. Am J Prev Med. 1998;14(4):245-58.

Anda RF, Felitti VJ, Bremner JD, et al. The enduring effects of abuse and related adverse experiences in childhood. A convergence of evidence from neurobiology and epidemiology. Eur Arch Psychiatry Clin Neurosci. 2006;256(3):174-86.
Hughes K, Bellis MA, Hardcastle KA, et al. The effect of multiple adverse childhood experiences on health: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Lancet Public Health. 2017;2(8):e356-e366.
formula: Sum of 'yes' responses to 10 ACE questions (range 0-10)
notes: The ACE questionnaire covers experiences during the first 18 years of life
Each 'yes' answer counts as 1 point toward the total score
The test does not account for positive childhood experiences that may provide resilience
Higher scores indicate increased risk but do not determine individual outcomes
This is a screening tool and should be used as part of comprehensive assessment
Cultural and contextual factors should be considered when interpreting results
The original study was conducted primarily on middle-class, educated, employed adults with health insurance
